author: By Alan Blinder
title: Wales Has a Prince, But It Has Never Hosted a British Open
description: The Open is being played for the 151st time, this time at Royal Liverpool in England. It has never once been to Wales.
content: The rain rat-a-tatted atop the umbrellas around Royal Liverpool Golf Club’s 17th green one afternoon this past week, the air so chilled that it did not feel like even an English summer. A veil of mist clouded the landscape. Still near enough to peek through, though, was the Welsh coast, a handful of long tee shots across the estuary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Ben Protess, Alan Feuer and Adam Goldman
title: As Inquiries Compound, Justice System Pours Resources Into Scrutinizing Trump
description: For all their complexity, the Trump-related prosecutions have not significantly constrained the ability of prosecutors to carry out their regular duties, officials have said.
content: Jack Smith, the special counsel overseeing criminal investigations into former President Donald J. Trump, employs 40 to 60 career prosecutors, paralegals and support staff, augmented by a rotating cast of F.B.I. agents and technical specialists, according to people familiar with the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Was the Rolled-Up Painting in the Dog Walker’s Closet Worth Millions?
description: The dog walker thought so. Sotheby’s planned the auction — at first.
content: In March of 2022, Mark Herman, a dog walker and recreational drug enthusiast in Upper Manhattan, came into possession of a dog, a painting and a story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Pretty (Devoted) in Pink: ‘Barbie’ Hordes Spill Into Theaters
description: Fans nationwide shopped their closets for the rosiest interpretations of the Barbie ethos: sparkly bags, open-toed pumps, stretchy headbands and more.
content: Karma Masselli woke up Thursday morning knowing it was a special day. The “Barbie” movie was finally here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Futurama’ Review: Latest Go-Round Mines the Past
description: The animated sci-fi comedy, now on Hulu as a reboot of a reboot of a reboot, is the same show as ever. For fans, that will be enough.
content: “Information wants to be free” may be a dubious maxim, but it has a more obviously true corollary: Intellectual property wants to be exploited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lily Burana
title: Yes, Shaun Cassidy Is Still Dreamy
description: A fan finds herself in a backstage hug, decades after she kissed her poster of the onetime teen idol.
content: I was approaching the George Washington Bridge when my friend Lynn fired a text into the Shaun Squad group chat: “GET READY, PARTY PEOPLE!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Pacific Seabed Mining Delayed as International Agency Finalizes Rules
description: Efforts to extract the metals used in car batteries have been pushed off amid pressure from environmentalists and nations that oppose them.
content: The start of industrial-scale seabed mining to extract car battery metals from the bottom of the Pacific Ocean has been delayed after the international agency charged with overseeing the work concluded late last week that it needed more time to finalize mining rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: A Crisis in America’s Theaters Leaves Prestigious Stages Dark
description: As they struggle to recover after the pandemic, regional theaters are staging fewer shows, giving fewer performances, laying off staff and, in some cases, closing.
content: There is less theater in America these days. Fewer venues. Fewer productions. Fewer performances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Barbie’ Box Office to the World: The Pandemic Is Officially Over
description: With the biggest revenues since 2019, “Barbenheimer” gives the usual franchises a run for their money, selling out even predawn screenings.
content: The movie business lives!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Former Republican Aides Shepherd Whistle-Blowers Through Congress
description: Empower Oversight, a group of lawyers including former aides to Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, is part of a constellation of groups facilitating G.O.P. investigations in Congress.
content: When Gary Shapley, a longtime I.R.S. investigator, wanted to air his accusations that the federal government had mishandled the tax investigation into President Biden’s son Hunter, the information he had was so sensitive he couldn’t even provide it to his own lawyer without potentially committing a felony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Crispin Sartwell
title: Can Jelly Roll Heal the Broken Soul of America?
description: In the outlaw country music star, millions like me seem to have found a preacher who delivers both reality and spirituality.
content: On one level — let’s call it the superficial level — the recent and rapid rise to stardom of Jason DeFord, the country singer and rapper known as Jelly Roll, might seem surprising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Cox, Jack D'Isidoro, Dan Powell, John Woo, Sophia Lanman and Devin Murphy
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Trillion-Gallon Question’
description: Extreme weather is threatening California’s dams. What happens if they fail?
content: On the morning of Feb. 7, 2017, two electricians were working on a warning siren near the spillway of Oroville Dam, 60 miles north of Sacramento, when they heard an explosion. As they watched, a giant plume of water rose over their heads, and chunks of concrete began flying down the hillside toward the Feather River. The dam’s spillway, a concrete channel capable of moving millions of gallons of water out of the reservoir in seconds, was disintegrating in front of them. If it had to be taken out of service, a serious rainstorm, like the one that had been falling on Northern California for days, could cause the dam — the tallest in the United States — to fail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Inconclusive Election Thrusts Spain Into Political Muddle
description: The returns showed no party winning the support needed to govern, leaving the country facing weeks of uncertainty.
content: Spain was thrust into political uncertainty on Sunday after national elections left no party with enough support to form a government, most likely resulting in weeks of horse trading or potentially a new vote later this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Brian Harman Romps to British Open Victory at Royal Liverpool
description: Harman, a 36-year-old American, came close to winning the 2017 U.S. Open, but his triumph on Sunday gave him his first major title.
content: Brian Harman knew Saturday evening that sleep might be hard to come by, as much as he knew he needed it. He had been in this situation — the 54-hole leader at a major tournament — six years ago and knew the agonizing cost of a fitful night: a runner-up finish, months and then years of what-ifs, a career not on the margins but not among the ultra-elite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Leily Nikounazar
title: It’s Scorching in Iran, and There’s Less and Less Water to Help
description: Water shortages from longtime mismanagement have left people with shrinking options, as temperatures spike and growing poverty makes air-conditioning unaffordable for many.
content: For a month and 10 days of unrelenting summer heat, Sepideh, a physician in southern Iran, and her dentist husband have left the house only for work (and only in the mornings) and for groceries (and only when the fridge is utterly bare). At one point last week, her car’s dashboard thermometer read 57 degrees Celsius, about 135 degrees Fahrenheit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: A Number That Should Guide Your Health Choices (It’s Not Your Age)
description: Life expectancy increasingly figures into calculations about whether screenings and treatments are appropriate. Here’s how to find out yours.
content: At her annual visit, the patient’s doctor asks if she plans to continue having regular mammograms to screen for breast cancer, and then reminds her that it’s been almost 10 years since her last colonoscopy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Jamaica gets an unexpected draw with France.
description: Despite a successful run in international play over the past few years, France has been in turmoil behind the scenes. In March, the French federation fired its longtime coach, Corinne Diacre, after players complained of an unhealthy environment on the team.
content: Despite a successful run in international play over the past few years, France has been in turmoil behind the scenes. In March, the French federation fired its longtime coach, Corinne Diacre, after players complained of an unhealthy environment on the team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: How to Improve a Summer Tomato Sandwich? Furikake.
description: Eric Kim has a new recipe for the seasonal favorite that plays the savoriness of the tomato against a Japanese spice blend.
content: Good morning. There may be no better summer sandwich than a tomato one, on white bread smeared wall-to-wall with mayonnaise and sprinkled lightly with flaky salt and a little cracked black pepper. I thought it unimprovable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Lisa Lerer
title: U.S. Confronts Tight but Turbulent Relationship With Israel
description: President Biden has cautioned Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu against pursuing a proposal to rein in Israel’s judiciary, a plan that has deeply divided Israeli society.
content: Long before moving into the White House, President Biden compared the relationship between the United States and Israel to that of close friends. “We love one another,” he said, “and we drive one another crazy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel’s Identity Hangs in Balance Ahead of Key Vote on New Law
description: Lawmakers are set to vote Monday on whether to limit the Supreme Court’s power as one element of a government plan to overhaul judicial authority. It is part of a profound rift over Israel’s nature and future.
content: When tens of thousands of Israelis marched up to Jerusalem this weekend to protest the far-right government’s plan to limit judicial power, many were driven by an urgent fear that the government is trying to steal the country that their parents and grandparents fought to build against the odds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arlene Dávila
title: Pedro Pascal and Jenna Ortega Shouldn’t Be Exceptions in Hollywood
description: There are generations of talented scriptwriters, producers, filmmakers who have been underutilized and countless rich stories and ideas that have yet to be told.
content: Corporate America’s treatment of Latinx people as a homogeneous monolithic group, instead of the diverse demographic it is, has for decades perpetuated stereotypes of Latino authenticity. These stereotypes have disproportionately depicted Latinos on TV and in movies as Spanish speakers that hailed from Latin America and shared a particular Latin “look.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
title: With Israel in Turmoil, Netanyahu Is Hospitalized for Pacemaker
description: Doctors said Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was “doing very well” after the unexpected procedure early Sunday, but the news only compounded the chaos over a government plan to limit judicial power.
content: With his country on knife’s edge over his campaign to rein in the power of the judiciary, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was rushed to the hospital early Sunday morning to have a heart pacemaker fitted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: Biden to Name National Monument for Emmett Till and His Mother
description: The monument, expected to be established on Tuesday, will consist of three protected sites in Illinois and Mississippi.
content: President Biden will establish a national monument on Tuesday honoring Emmett Till, the Black teenager who was brutally killed in 1955, and paying tribute to his mother, Mamie Till-Mobley, according to White House officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Raging Fires on Greek Island Force Thousands to Scramble for Refuge
description: As firefighters fought blazes kindled by tinder-dry conditions, the authorities sent tourists and residents on Rhodes to schools, gyms and boats moored at the port for shelter.
content: For the sixth day in a row, firefighters were battling on Sunday to douse blazes on the Greek island of Rhodes that have trapped thousands of tourists and locals, forcing many to spend the night in hotel lobbies, gymnasiums, schools or boats docked at the port.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Reduce the High Rates of Maternal Mortality
description: Responses to a doctor’s guest essay. Also: U.S.-China relations; underpaid teachers; admissions at Harvard; ending “holds” in the Senate.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamilton Cain
title: Regarding North Bath, Richard Russo Saved His Best for Last
description: Like “Nobody’s Fool” and “Everybody’s Fool,” “Somebody’s Fool” is set in a fictional town with lots of problems.
content: Welcome back to North Bath, scrappy sibling to the larger, wealthier Schuyler Springs, down the road in woodsy upstate New York. While Schuyler Springs is famous for wine bars, pricey restaurants and a racetrack, North Bath (or “Bath”) prides itself on a rustic vibe, greasy spoons and scrapyards and grand Victorian fixer-uppers. Here everyone knows your name. Burgers and pitchers of beer are just a stroll away, and bed-hopping is a town sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Vivek Shankar
title: Deadly Russian Strikes Hit Odesa Cathedral and Apartment Buildings
description: Moscow has renewed its attacks on the port city since pulling out of the Black Sea grain deal last week.
content: The civilian toll is rising in Odesa, the Ukrainian port city that has been under relentless attack by Russian forces in the past week after the Kremlin pulled out of an agreement that allowed for the export of Ukrainian grain through the Black Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Rethinking the Circus
description: Can Cirque du Soleil get Gen Z’s attention?
content: The idea of Cirque du Soleil might invite images of extravagant live shows with clowns, acrobats and fire breathers. The company is trying to change that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: What I Learned in Ukraine
description: Memo from a nation of closed skies, air-raid apps and bustling urban life.
content: WARSAW — Last week, a friend asked me what I could learn from a four-day trip to Ukraine I was planning that I couldn’t glean just by reading the news. It was a fair question. With the trip now behind me, I can answer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 23, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 23, 2023.
content: An article on Page 34 this weekend about Wikipedia and artificial intelligence refers imprecisely to what Margaret Mitchell has said about why she was fired from Google. She has said she was fired for criticizing how the company treated colleagues working on bias in A.I., not for criticizing the direction of its work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller and Shawn Hubler
title: In San Francisco, a Levi Strauss Heir and a Former Ally Prepare to Challenge London Breed
description: The mayor is drawing challengers more than a year before the election, a sign that she will face a tough race in a city where most voters remain in a foul mood.
content: London Breed sailed to victory as the mayor of San Francisco. A local who rose from the housing projects to become the first Black woman to lead the liberal city, she won a special election in 2018 and then a full term in a landslide the following year. Times were good; the pandemic had yet to happen. If homelessness and crime worried San Franciscans, few of them blamed her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Only Biden Can Save Israel Now
description: Mr. President, this Israeli government needs another dose of your tough love about our shared interests and about U.S. strategic interests.
content: Dear President Biden:
source.name: The New York Times

title: 50 Rappers, 50 Stories: Behind the Scenes
description: A look at how we assembled a sweeping collection of personal narratives, and the threads that tie them together.
content: This week, The New York Times published 50 Rappers, 50 Stories, a collection of oral histories gathered from hip-hop artists across generations, regions and styles. It includes testimonials from superstars like Lil Wayne, 50 Cent, Cardi B and Eminem; local heroes like Project Pat, Uncle Luke, Bun B and Krayzie Bone; and outlier champions like Trippie Redd, stic, Slug and Boots Riley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Rebecca Robbins
title: Drugmakers Are ‘Throwing the Kitchen Sink’ to Halt Medicare Price Negotiations
description: The government will soon announce the first 10 medications that will be subject to price negotiations with Medicare under a new law. Drugmakers are fighting the measure in court.
content: The pharmaceutical industry, which suffered a stinging defeat last year when President Biden signed a law authorizing Medicare to negotiate the price of some prescription medicines, is now waging a broad-based assault on the measure — just as the negotiations are about to begin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Ann Roth Is Hollywood’s Secret Weapon
description: Inside the studio of the costume master who helped give the world “Klute,” “The English Patient,” “Midnight Cowboy,” “Working Girl,” “Mamma Mia!” “Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom” — and more.
content: Ann Roth began with a few instructions: “Do NOT call me amazing. Do NOT call me a 91-year-old legend. Do NOT call me the oldest person in the ‘Barbie’ movie.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Friendly Gathering
description: With this theme, John Ewbank traces a clear arc.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Tony Bennett Used His Celebrity to Promote Civil Rights
description: The singer witnessed racism in the military and in the music industry, experiences that informed his decision to join the Selma-to-Montgomery march in 1965.
content: In explaining the roots of his commitment to civil rights, Tony Bennett often told a story from his Army days, when he brought a Black soldier as his guest to Thanksgiving dinner, prompting a furious reprimand and a demotion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sergey Radchenko
title: Vladimir Putin Is Still Useful to Xi Jinping. Until He Isn’t.
description: China’s track record on foreign friendships does not bode well for the Russian leader.
content: In 1969, China and the Soviet Union seemed on the brink of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Spain’s Vote on Sunday: Here’s What to Know
description: The national elections could see a far-right party enter the Spanish government for the first time since the 1970s.
content: Spaniards went to the polls on Sunday to vote in an early general election that could see the right return to power and, more crucially, the far right enter the national government for the first time since the Franco dictatorship, nearly a half-century ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: In Louisiana, a Democratic Governor Leans on Vetoes to Stall Conservative Agenda
description: John Bel Edwards, the only Democratic governor in the Deep South, has successfully vetoed bills that have glided into law elsewhere in the region. Soon, he’ll leave office.
content: The Republican supermajority in the Louisiana State Legislature pushed through a bill this year banning gender-transition care for minors, along with other legislation banning Covid vaccine requirements in schools and any classroom discussion of gender identity and sexual orientation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Jonas Vingegaard Wins Tour de France Again After Vanquishing His Rival
description: What started as a tense two-man battle became a foregone conclusion when Tadej Pogacar couldn’t stay with Vingegaard in the 17th stage of the race.
content: When Tadej Pogacar slipped behind Jonas Vingegaard on the Col de la Loze mountain pass through the Alps on Wednesday, eight kilometers and a world away from the top of the hot, punishing climb, it was only briefly unclear why. Pogacar’s own voice, over his team’s radio and broadcast on television during the Tour de France’s 17th stage, provided an immediate explanation for the rare sight of him being left behind like a mere mortal.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘She Proceeded to Empty the Bag’s Contents Onto the Small Table’
description: A surprising response to a compliment, a circle of urban life and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aida Alami and Monique Jaques
title: The Morocco Women’s Team Has Already Won
description: Morocco is the first North African and majority Arab nation to qualify for the Women’s World Cup. It’s hoping to pick up the baton its men’s team carried in Qatar.
content: Khadija Rmichi’s path to the Women’s World Cup started on a bicycle.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Story of Arab Loss Comes to Life at a Kibbutz in Israel, 75 Years Later
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 23, 2023
content: “There is no point in trying to erase history. It never disappears.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Dorrance Dance and a Mythili Prakash Premiere at Jacob’s Pillow
description: Stormy weather at a summer festival wraps performances of a debut and some classic works by two very distinct choreographers.
content: Rain was in the forecast here at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival on Friday, but the first rumble came from inside the Ted Shawn Theater. It was partway through the matinee performance of Dorrance Dance and the lights were dimmed. The dancers had spread themselves around the auditorium and were drumming the floor and walls, working up a storm in surround sound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elise Young
title: In Philadelphia, City Pools Bring Relief as Closed Ones Stir Frustration
description: The continuing shortage of lifeguards has hindered the city’s efforts to open facilities, leaving some neighborhoods feeling neglected.
content: At their neighborhood pool in West Philadelphia, Markyda Anderson’s little boys could not wait to get back in. They had grown tired of playing in a nearby splash pad as lifeguards conducted a periodic check of chlorine levels. So once the break was over and swimmers were welcome again, they dashed back and — plunk, plunk — into the water they went.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: A ‘Leaner-Meaner’ DeSantis Campaign Faces a Reboot and a Reckoning
description: The campaign’s missteps and swelling costs have made donors and allies anxious. One person close to the Florida governor said he had experienced a “challenging learning curve.”
content: Throughout the spring, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and his advisers waved off his sagging poll numbers with the simple fact that he wasn’t yet an actual candidate for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: A New Arrival in ‘The Country of the Blind’
description: In his memoir, Andrew Leland discovers that slowly losing one’s sight offers a special understanding of vision — and its limits.
content: After reading Andrew Leland’s memoir, “The Country of the Blind,” you will look at the English language differently. You will even look at the word “look” differently. (And, at intervals: “reading.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Marina Trahan Martinez
title: Bungled Hiring of Journalism Director Exposes a Rift at Texas A&M
description: The failed effort to hire Kathleen McElroy, a journalism professor who ultimately turned down what she said was a watered-down offer, has revealed wide divisions at the school over diversity.
content: At a meeting with student leaders in February 2022, the president of Texas A&M University described an ambitious plan to confront the school’s biggest challenges and turn it into a world class institution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: A Major Vote in Israel
description: Also, Cambodia’s elections, Ukraine’s counteroffensive and Japan’s coal plants.
content: Israeli lawmakers are expected to hold a binding vote today on one part of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s plan to overhaul the judiciary. It will come after a weekend of protest and turmoil, and the issue has become a proxy for a broader emotional and even existential battle about the nature of the Israeli state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak, Dzvinka Pinchuk, Yurii Shyvala and Mauricio Lima
title: Weary Soldiers, Unreliable Munitions: Ukraine’s Many Challenges
description: A month of reporting by New York Times journalists found the fighting mostly stalemated and Ukraine facing an array of obstacles against a determined foe.
content: The headquarters of one of the battalions in Ukraine’s 53rd Mechanized Brigade smells of freshly cut pine trees. The scents are from the wooden support beams in the labyrinth of trenches that make up most of the unit’s rudimentary base outside the embattled town of Avdiivka.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: How a Mexican Lager Quietly Rose to Become America’s Best-Selling Beer
description: A decade before Bud Light faced a conservative-led boycott over a transgender influencer, Modelo Especial was on track to take the No. 1 spot.
content: More beers in America are being paired with lime than ever before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: Rising Heat Deaths Are Not Just About the Temperature
description: It is unconscionable that in our wealthy country, we let blue-collar workers and the economically disadvantaged needlessly die in oppressive heat.
content: The day I found out that 10 people had died of heat-related illness in Laredo, Texas, I happened to be on a road trip with my daughter from our home in Austin to the Gulf Coast. Our hotel had a pool with an outdoor bar. As I read about this tragedy on a cushioned lounge chair, the contrast between these horrific deaths, just a few hours away, and the happy sunbathers sipping boozy frozen drinks around me was troubling and revelatory. We are all experiencing record-breaking heat, but it’s clear that we do not all experience it in the same way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Cheri Pies, Who Guided Lesbian Couples in Parenthood, Dies at 73
description: She made her name with a watershed book for same-sex parents and later studied the impact of racial and economic inequality on health.
content: Cheri Pies, a professor of public health who broke barriers with her landmark 1985 book, “Considering Parenthood: A Workbook for Lesbians,” a bible of the “gayby boom” of the 1980s and beyond, died on July 4 at her home in Berkeley, Calif. She was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Well-Traveled Stars Find Their Forever Home in Cooperstown
description: Fred McGriff played for six franchises and Scott Rolen played for four, but consistent production, and lots of determination, got them into the Baseball Hall of Fame.
content: Fred McGriff played for six franchises, so many that his new plaque at the Hall of Fame has no logo on the cap. Scott Rolen represents the St. Louis Cardinals, but he played for four teams in all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: ‘Henri VIII,’ an Operatic Rarity About a Tudor Tyrant
description: Saint-Saëns’s 1883 work is seldom performed today, but it is being well staged and excitingly sung at Bard College.
content: Henry VIII was, by many accounts, an intelligent and sophisticated man — an author and reader, a musician and composer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber and Ryan Mac
title: Elon Musk Says Twitter Will Change Its Logo
description: The tech billionaire indicated he would replace the company’s blue bird silhouette with an X.
content: Elon Musk said he was about to make one of the most visible changes to Twitter since he took control of the social media company last fall: replacing its widely recognized bird logo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Are Google and Meta to Blame for the Racist Massacre in Buffalo?
description: Two new lawsuits filed by the victims’ families are the most recent attempt to hold social media companies responsible when men steeped in violent ideologies on those platforms open fire.
content: Ask the families of the victims of last year’s racist massacre in Buffalo what they want and one goal comes up again and again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: 4 Killed in Helicopter Crash in Remote Alaskan Lake
description: The victims included a pilot and three people who worked for the Alaska Division of Geological and Geophysical Surveys, officials said.
content: A helicopter carrying a pilot and three passengers who had been conducting field work for an Alaskan government agency crashed on Thursday night, killing all four people on board, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Firefighter Dies After ‘Targeted Attack’ on an Alabama Fire Station
description: A second firefighter was also shot in the attack at a Birmingham fire station this month. A motive for the shooting is unknown.
content: The authorities in Birmingham, Ala., are searching for leads and a motive in a daytime shooting at a city firehouse this month that left one on-duty firefighter dead and another wounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘New York, New York’ Will End Its Abbreviated Run on Broadway
description: The big-budget musical that tried to position itself as a nostalgic love letter to the city will close after a summer of dropping sales.
content: “New York, New York,” a big-budget musical that tried to position itself as a nostalgic love letter to the city, will close on July 30 after underwhelming critics and failing to find a sufficient audience to sustain a Broadway run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By K.K. Rebecca Lai and Ben Blatt
title: Watch Amateurs Race Against the Tour de France’s Top Climbers (Sort Of)
description: Thousands of amateurs tried the same steep climbs that Tour cyclists did, and uploaded their rides to Strava.
content: Thousands of amateurs tried the same steep climbs that Tour cyclists did, and uploaded their rides to Strava.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martín González Gómez and Lauren Leatherby
title: Spain General Election Results
description: See results, maps and analysis from the general election in Spain.
content: See results, maps and analysis from the general election in Spain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Wildfires on Greek Island Force Mass Evacuations
description: Thousands of tourists and residents spent the night in makeshift shelters as raging blazes threatened seaside areas on Rhodes.
content: Thousands of tourists and residents spent the night in makeshift shelters as raging blazes threatened seaside areas on Rhodes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Russian Attack on Odesa Badly Damages Historic Cathedral
description: Overnight Russian missile strikes damaged Odesa’s largest Orthodox cathedral. The attack on the city killed one person and injured 22 others, according to Ukrainian officials.
content: Overnight Russian missile strikes damaged Odesa’s largest Orthodox cathedral. The attack on the city killed one person and injured 22 others, according to Ukrainian officials.
source.name: The New York Times
